Equipping Rural Farmers on Healthier Food Production
Equipping Rural Farmers on Healthier Food Production

The objectives of this subject are to:
1. Introduce to students the concept and practice of service learning
2. Raise students’ awareness of food production issues in China and educate them on the challenges and needs of underprivileged communities in China
3. Get the students be educated on the basic concept and practice on modern agriculture and aquaculture
4. Raise students’ awareness of agricultural and food supply chain issues in China and educate them the technological feasible alternatives and challenges 5. Let the students to have hands-on experience and knowing the need, inadequacy and limitation on good agricultural operation for effective and safe production of better agriculture produces
6. Enhance students’ generic competencies of innovative problem solving, communication and teamwork 7. Nurture students’ sense of social awareness, responsibility and engagement Upon completion of the subject, students will be able to:
a. Link their service learning activities and experiences with the academic content of the subject b. Enhance students’ competencies in career development on farming and related businesses through partial exemption to be an internationally recognized Farm Assurer
c. Understanding the environmental damages and impact of different form of agriculture and aquaculture practices
d. Apply the knowledge and skills they have acquired in university education to deal with complex issues in the service setting
e. Work effectively in teams to solve problems encountered in planning and delivering the service
f. Communicate effectively with clients and/or other stakeholders g. Demonstrate empathy for people in need and a sense of civic responsibility
h. Reflect on their role and responsibilities both as a professional in their chosen discipline and/or as a responsible citizen"

The specialisation module presented in this manual is titled “Building Resilient Communities”. The module focuses on building the competence of students to deal with complex problems and finding solutions for improved disaster risk management. Particularly those competences will be developed concerning experimenting with innovative approaches to analyse and solve existing problems or challenges in risk management while dealing with multiple stakeholders and actors and working across different scales.

Intercultural Understanding through Film examines the basic concepts of how to cross cultural bridges through film. The course will use three films for viewing and then discussing cultural differences and similarities based upon three regions of the world.If you remain engaged in this course and participate to the fullest extent, you should:? Develop an understanding of cultural differences and worldviews through film.? Explore your individual cultural identity.? Develop insights into cultural dimensions to help you cross cultural bridges with people who are different than you.
Intercultural Communication and Global Social Responsibility
Intercultural Communication and Global Social Responsibility

Intercultural Communication examines the concepts associated with culture and communication and how this relates to global leadership. The course will use case studies and problem based learning to analyze intercultural communication situations; and integrates conceptual understanding with “real life” intercultural experiences and observations in leadership – from both an Eastern and Western perspective. After taking this course you will have a deeper self-awareness of who you are as a global citizen, as well as be able to identify intercultural issues relating to social responsibility in business and the professions.

Natural hazards have the potential to affect every person on Earth, regardless of nationality, race, wealth or level of education. In recent years, we have seen the impacts of such events rise, as population pressures have forced communities to live in hazardous locations and as the climate continues to change. Given such facts, it is important that younger generations are armed with relevant knowledge concerning such events and that is the aim of this course.The course will introduce a range of natural hazard events, ranging from geological hazards, such as earthquakes and volcanoes, to hydro-meteorological hazards such as hurricanes and floods. It will present the causes of such events, discussing the physical scientific processes that generate them and their interrelatedness, while also highlighting the role that societies have in compounding, or indeed in some cases, generating, their widespread impacts. The idea that “Earthquakes don’t kill, buildings do”, will also be explored, along with a consideration of hazard occurrence frequency, magnitude and probability.Following a grounding in these fundamental topics, the concept of the ‘Disaster Management Cycle’ will be presented, focusing on what societies can do to either prevent, mitigate or predict future natural hazard events. Successful and unsuccessful examples of prevention, mitigation and prediction will be presented, with students also given the opportunity to develop their own early-warning messages. The course will end with a consideration of the future prospects for managing these natural, but often devastating, events, showing that we may never be able to stop them but that we might be able to reduce the tragic impacts they often have.The intended learning outcomes are that, on completion of this course, the student should be able to:1. Describe the physical processes associated with various natural hazards.2. Understand the interrelated nature of natural hazards.3. Appreciate that the effects of natural hazards are often the result of human activity or inactivity.4. Explain the different methods and the techniques forpreventing, predicting and mitigating against natural hazards.

Natural and socio-technological disasters are a major global issue. There is evidence that disasters are occurring with increasing frequency and intensity and, most importantly, having greater impact. Effective risk communication can help the public to understand potential risks and be able to prepare and respond to the hazards. It can also help experts to provide practical information more effectively. This course will start with the investigation of factors that affect risk perception from psychological, social, cultural and political perspectives. It will then examine the concepts and approaches of effective risk communication. Methods of communicating risk with stakeholders will be evaluated. The role and challenges of using social media in risk communication will be critically examined. In addition, it will investigate issues associated with risk reduction through warning and informing. To achieve this, the course will explore issues for public education and raising awareness. Hands-on session will be introduced to enhance students’ experiential learning.Indicative learning outcomes include: 1. Assess the factors that affect perception of risk held by practitioners and the public and how information about environmental risk can be disseminated effectively.2. Risk communication and its role in the adoption and implementation of mitigative actions; decision making process, influence and perception of risk.3. Assess the components of an early warning system in the context of reducing risk to natural and environmental hazards.4. Examples of public awareness programmes including information sources and message characteristics. 5. Critically evaluate approaches to deliver effective disaster risk reduction education.
